data.title: B. Board: In memory of Flyface, Gravel Gertie, Mumbles, L’il Abner, and Kickapoo Joy Juice!
data.meta_description: Funny business (responsorial)Wednesday’s Bulletin Board included a note from W.i. Fly of Austin: “Chester Gould was the creator of the popular ‘Dick Tracy’ comic strip. data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

Funny business (responsorial)

Wednesday’s Bulletin Board included a note from W.i. Fly of Austin: “Chester Gould was the creator of the popular ‘Dick Tracy’ comic strip. My pen name, Fly, comes from Flyface in the strip.

“This morning I remembered one of his characters, Gravel Gertie [Gertrude Plenty]. Back in the day, his readers got involved. Gould had a contest to name this uncomely lady with a face like 5 miles of bad road. Evidently ‘Gravel Gertie’ was the winning name.

“The Tracy strip also had a drink that was called Kickapoo Joy Juice. I think Li’l Abner drank that.”

BULLETIN BOARD SAID: “Well, yes, Li’l Abner did drink Kickapoo Joy Juice — but not in ‘Dick Tracy.’ He drank it in a little comic strip, by Al Capp, called … ‘Li’l Abner’!”

We presently heard from The Cab Driver of South St. Paul: “If you went and did a Google search on ‘Li’l Abner,’ I think you’d then remember that Li’l Abner was pure as the driven snow: He’d never touch a drop of Kickapoo Joy Juice! The characters in the strip who did drink Kickapoo Joy Juice wouldn’t pass the politically correct standards of today. And that’s fact!”

And from Mattzdad of Rochester: “W.i. Fly’s ‘Dick Tracy’ comments put me in mind of my favorite ‘DT’ character, Mumbles the bandleader, who would book a gig and then rob the party and escape, usually with Tracy somehow in pursuit. Gould had a way of creating great names and great cartoon characters.”

Muse, amuse

Leading to: What’s in a name? (responsorial)

IGHGrampa: “Speculation about what the child of Alley Oop and Betty Boop would be named [BB, 2/17/2016]:

“Since he is named after his father, he would be Alley, Jr. If he became a newspaper reporter and got a nickname, he might become Alley ‘Scoop’ Boop-Oop, Jr.

“Given the unusual appearance of his parents, I wonder what he might look like. Alley, Sr. was a big, hairy guy with oversized forearms and lower legs. (Might he be related to Popeye?) Betty was a petite little lady with a large head, dark curly hair and a very small chin. So Alley, Jr. might be a big hairy guy with oversized forearms and lower legs with an oversized head, small chin and dark, curly hair.

“Alley Oop did have a girlfriend, whose name was Ooola. If she and Alley ever got married, then she’d be Ooola Oop. If they had a son who became a tuba player, he might be Ooompa Booompa Oop.”

The unrespected, respected! (resp’l)

First, Friendly Bob of Fridley: “A big thanks to IGHGrampa for his recognition of the tuba player in polka bands (BB, 2/15/2016). This really struck a nice chord with me, a veteran old tuba player.

“I started playing the tuba in fourth grade, and continued with school bands through 12th grade, and even in my Navy boot-camp band (where I had lighter duty, being in a ‘special’ company). While I was still in high school, and later, before I joined the Navy, I played for a couple of years with a polka band that usually consisted of an accordion player, a drummer, and me. I also subbed with a few other bands on occasion, and all of those gigs were great fun.

“One of my real joys as a young feller was when I got to play with well-known local artist and Minnesota Music Hall of Famer Roman Rezac, from the Lonsdale/Webster area. I managed that through several musician connections, and was a bit stunned when my friend Mert asked me to step in. Roman died in 2010, and I am sure that many of his recordings survive. I have several old vinyl records of his music, mostly under the Pleasant Peasant label.

“For most of my polka playing, I used my own Reynolds Sousaphone, which I purchased in New Ulm (where else?) in the late 1960s. I still have that old horn, though I have not tooted it for years. After I left the Navy, I did have a couple more gigs, but nothing regular. Sure, it is a bit heavy, but at least with the Sousaphone, that weight can be borne on a shoulder.

“I am ‘considering’ joining my heavy-brass brothers at next year’s Tuba Christmas, but I am not sure the lips still work. I am at least confident I can still do the fingerings that got thoroughly ingrained in my brain from playing all those years.

“Thanks again for the stroll down Memory Lane.”

Taxman: “The Bride (a.k.a. DebK of Rosemount) is at our little farm while I’m busy in town trying to earn a living. So she doesn’t get the paper until I deliver it. It felt pretty good to toss Monday’s paper in her lap and warn her not to miss BB. I get that same warning pretty often. (Yes, sometimes I have to be encouraged to read even the stories written by The Bride herself — but, really, I already know everything she writes about.) Anyway, it didn’t take long for The Bride to figure out that I wanted her to focus on the piece from IGHGrampa, which revealed that I am NOT alone in liking ‘Funtime Polka’ on Pioneer Public TV.

“She’s a good cook and all, but The Bride is a music snob and has been known to make fun of my taste in music, especially of my enjoyment of old-time music. Over the years, we have compromised. She gets to listen to the Saturday opera on MPR, and I get my Saturday fix of ‘Funtime Polka.’ When my show is on, The Bride pretends to be focused on her crossword puzzle. But I see her toes tapping.”

The Permanent Paternal Record

The Gram With a Thousand Rules: “My kids bought some old Hula Hoops at a garage sale back in the early ’70s. They were not having much luck mastering them when my dad arrived. Dad jumped out of his car and grabbed one of the Hula Hoops and said: ‘Here’s how you do it!’

“Now, my dad was in his 80s, and I had never seen him with a Hula Hoop. He was great at softball, terrific at pool, merciless at family touch-football games, and a pretty good bowler — but Hula Hooping?

“Daddy took the Hula Hoop, set it on end and gave it a hefty roll. As it rolled across the yard, we were all stunned to watch him as he darted in and out, in and out, in and out of the rolling hoop all the way to the end of our lot.

“The kids were kept busy all the rest of the summer, trying in vain to duplicate his feat.

“There was nobody like my dad. He really was the only one.”

Vanity, thy name is…

Red’s Offspring, north of St. Paul: “This personalized plate was on a GMC in the parking lot of the Shoreview Target: ‘SCOOBYD.’ The bracket for the plate was somewhat dog-eared, but no other clue about the vehicle’s possible occupant(s) was visible.”

Norsky: “Came upon a black Lexus SUV at a traffic light on Radio Drive in Woodbury Friday afternoon. The license plate read ‘ICUUCME.’ Reminded me of a line in one of those Ben Stiller/Robert De Niro movies, like ‘Meet the Fockers’: ‘I’m watching you watching me.’ ”

BULLETIN BOARD SAYS: It’s “Little Fockers.” Watch him watching him watching him, at tinyurl.com/watching-watching.

Our times

Birdwatcher in La Crescent: “While I was in the car today, I had the radio on and wasn’t paying too much attention to what was being said, but my ears pricked up when I heard the person saying that the worst part of being a parent is the potty training. Huh? I disagree; I think the worst part is raising a teenager — but I am sure not all parents will agree with me. He went on to say that there is now such a thing as a Potty Training School where they will teach you how to go about this training, how to discipline for accidents, and how to reward for not dirtying the pants. They will even come out to the house to help and instruct.

“I can’t believe I was able to potty-train four children without professional help, and they succeeded in about two weeks. I must have been a genius.

“What is this world coming to?”

Our birds, ourselves

Including: Today’s helpful hint

Dee of Inver Grove Heights: “It was mentioned in BB that a person doesn’t often see two pileated woodpeckers at once. We live in Inver Grove Heights, and we saw two pileateds this a.m. Also: Another day previously, two were here.

“We make our own suet, and birds love it. Pileateds come at mealtime — 8, 12 and 4. They have a schedule, too!

“Bird suet:

“1 cup crunchy peanut butter

“2 cups oatmeal

“2 cups cornmeal

“1 cup lard

“1 cup flour

“Melt peanut butter and lard. Add rest of ingredients. (Hubby adds some bird seed, optional.) Birds love it, bird lovers!”

Band Name of the Day: Ooola Oop and Her Hula Hoops

Website of the Day, from Double Bogey Mike:

The Flower Carpet of Brussels, at flowercarpet.be/en
